title: 115_s1562
content: The Act may be cited as the "North Korean Enablers Accountability Act of 2017". The Government of North Korea has violated multiple UN Security Council Resolutions by developing nuclear and missile programs. They also commit human rights abuses. The US and its partners aim for peaceful denuclearization through pressure and engagement. Sanctions imposed on the government of North Korea and its supporters for violating UN resolutions on nuclear and missile programs and human rights abuses. The President will block transactions involving property of individuals described in subsection (d) and impose restrictions on foreign financial institutions facilitating significant transactions with North Korea after 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The President will impose sanctions on any person who imports, purchases, or transfers goods or services from the Government of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea or any entity owned or controlled by the government. The President will impose sanctions on any person affiliated with entities identified by the Secretary of the Treasury as major importers of goods from the Government of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. Sanctions exemptions include activities subject to reporting requirements under title V of the National Security Act of 1947, authorized US intelligence activities, and activities necessary to comply with international agreements. Activities incidental to the POW/MIA accounting mission in North Korea, including efforts by the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency and other organizations recovering remains of US Armed Forces members, can be exempt from sanctions if deemed in the national security interest and reported to congressional committees by the President. The President may waive sanctions for humanitarian purposes or assistance by submitting a written determination to congressional committees. The determination must be renewed every 30 days to one year. The President may waive sanctions for humanitarian purposes or assistance by submitting a written determination to congressional committees, including notification and accountability controls to ensure activities are humanitarian or for specified purposes. Internationally recognized humanitarian organizations are not subject to sanctions for engaging in financial transactions. Individuals can engage in financial transactions, transport goods or services, or have contact with individuals under sanctions for humanitarian purposes under a waiver issued by the President. Sanctions can be imposed on individuals without their names being published in the Federal Register or the list of specially designated nationals. Definitions in this section include "appropriate congressional committees" and terms related to correspondent and payable-through accounts. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as "correspondent account," "payable-through account," "foreign financial institution," "humanitarian assistance," and "knowingly." These definitions are important for understanding the regulations outlined in the text. The term "United States person" includes a US citizen, a lawful permanent resident, or an entity organized under US laws. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON IMPORT OF AND SANCTIONS WITH RESPECT TO GOODS MADE WITH NORTH KOREAN LABOR. Prohibition on Import of Goods Made With North Korean Labor, stating that goods produced by North Korean labor are deemed to be made by convict, forced, or indentured labor and are not allowed entry into the United States, with an exception if clear evidence is provided by the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The President can block transactions of persons using North Korean labor to produce goods prohibited from entering the US, defined as labor procured through trafficking. "Trafficked labor involves procuring labor or services through force, fraud, or coercion for involuntary servitude, peonage, debt bondage, or slavery." The Securities and Exchange Commission will require issuers to disclose investments in North Korea and other sanctionable activities within 270 days of this Act's enactment. The term "issuer" is defined as per the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
